TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, smectitic, calcareous, mesic Fluvaquentic Endoaquolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Malin clay loam, irrigated pasture.  (Colors are for moist soil unless otherwise noted.)
Ap--0 to 6 inches; black (10YR 2/1) clay loam, dark gray (N 4/0) dry; moderate medium angular blocky structure; very hard, friable, sticky and plastic; many very fine roots; many very fine pores; slightly effervescent; strongly alkaline (pH 8.7); abrupt smooth boundary.  (0 to 10 inches thick)
Akn--6 to 14 inches; black (N 2/0) silty clay, gray (N 5/0) dry; common fine grayish brown mottles; moderate medium angular blocky structure; very hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; common very fine roots; common very fine tubular pores; continuous stress cutans on ped surfaces; strongly effervescent; very strongly alkaline (pH 9.1); clear smooth boundary.  (3 to 14 inches thick)
Bkn1--14 to 21 inches; black (10YR 2/1) clay loam, gray (N 6/0) dry; many medium dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) mottles; moderate fine angular blocky structure; very hard, firm, sticky and plastic; common very fine roots; common fine and very fine tubular pores; strongly effervescent; strongly alkaline (pH 8.8); clear smooth boundary.  (3 to 14 inches thick)
Bkn2--21 to 43 inches; very dark grayish brown (2.5Y 3/2) clay loam, gray (N 6/0) dry; common medium dark grayish brown (2.5Y 4/2) mottles; massive; hard, firm, sticky and plastic; few very fine roots; many fine and very fine tubular pores; strongly effervescent; strongly alkaline (pH 8.8); clear smooth boundary.  (10 to 30 inches thick)
Bk--43 to 64 inches; very dark grayish brown (2.5Y 3/2) clay loam, light gray (10YR 7/1) dry; common medium dark grayish brown (2.5Y 4/2) mottles; massive; very hard, firm, sticky and plastic; few very fine roots; many fine and very fine tubular pores; strongly effervescent; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Klamath County, Oregon; in the south end of Poe Valley; 2,100 feet east and 1,600 feet south of the northwest corner of section 35, T. 39 S., R. 11-1/2 E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The mean annual soil temperature is 47 to 51 degrees F.  SAR is 20 to 30 in the mollic epipedon, decreasing at depth below 20 inches.  Electrical conductivity is 2 to 16 mmhos. throughout.  The soil is calcareous in all parts with disseminated carbonates.  The mollic epipedon is 10 to 24 inches thick.  The particle-size control section has 35 to 50 percent clay and more than 15 percent coarser than very fine sand.  Organic matter content decreases irregularly with depth.
The Ap and Akn horizon has value of 2 or 3 moist, 4 or 5 dry, and chroma of 0 or 1 moist and dry.  It is strongly or very strongly alkaline.
The Bkn and Bk horizon has hue of 2.5Y or 10YR value of 3 to 5 moist, 5 to 7 dry, and chroma of 0 to 2 moist and dry.  It is clay loam, silty clay loam or silty clay, with strata of sandy clay loam.  SAR is 13 to 30 decreasing with depth.  It is moderately or strongly alkaline decreasing with depth.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Bigmeadow, Humboldt, and Stillwater series.  Bigmeadow soils have over 60 percent clay in the particle-size control section and a mean annual soil temperature of 53 to 57 degrees F.  Humboldt soils have less than 15 percent exchangeable sodium and less than 15 percent coarser than very fine sand.  Stillwater soils have less than 15 percent exchangeable sodium, have A horizons with 1 to 2 percent organic matter and have mean annual soil temperature ranging from 53 to 57 degrees F.  All of the competing series have less than 8 inches of precipitation.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Malin soils are on flood plains and lake bottoms.  Slopes are 0 to 1 percent.  Elevations are 4,050 to 4,750 feet.  The soils formed in alluvial and lacustrine sediments weathered from tuff, basalt, diatomite, and ash.  The climate is characterized by hot dry summers and cool wet winters.  The mean annual precipitation is 10 to 16 inches.  The mean January temperature is 28 degrees F., the mean July temperature is 67 degrees F., and the mean annual temperature is 45 to 49 degrees F.  The frost-free period is 50 to 110 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Bedner, Calder, Hosley, Lakeview, Pit and Scherrard soils.  Bedner soils are nonsodic and have duripans at 20 to 40 inches.  Calder soils are nonsodic, have an ochric epipedon and have a duripan at 10 to 20 inches.  Hosley and Scherrard soils have a duripan at 20 to 40 inches.  Lakeview soils are moderately well drained, nonsodic, and average 25 to 35 percent clay.  Pit soils are nonsodic and have intersecting slickensides.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Poorly drained; slow permeability.  A water table is at 1 foot above the surface to 4 feet below the surface from March to June (spring snowmelt period).

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Malin soils are used for irrigated pasture and wildlife habitat.  Vegetation is dominantly inland saltgrass and nuttall alkaligrass.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Lake basins in south-central Oregon, MLRA 21.  The soils are moderately extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Davis, California

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic horizons and other features recognized in this pedon are:
Mollic epipedon:  the zone from 0 to 14 inches (Ap, Akn horizons)
Aquoll:  Aquic soil moisture regime, SAR greater than 13 in the mollic epipedon and decreases with depth.
Fluvaquentic:  Irregular decrease in organic matter with depth.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
